topic.title: Twitter found at least 926 accounts with suspicious of Thailand army's information operation
topic.body:
According to Twitter's report, said that about 926 Twitter accounts are related to Thailand army's information operation. Deputy Chief of Staff Santipong Thampiya, by the time, had declined. "We didn't have any IO or related. Also as our social media accounts are purposely used for publicize and help people.", Said Santipong.

As the side of Thai army's spokesman, also said this was not justified, due to lack of deep analysis of those anonymous accounts, not their own official.

Reference: https://www.blognone.com/node/118929 (Thai)

topic.title: Please help poor Thailand by signing this petition.
I'm curious, is there anyone who can bring ZeroNet or Freenet as a dedicated network into a private or totally isolated environment (like, into Cuba for example)
topic.body:
I've seen this vlog from http://127.0.0.1:43110/149EPBN4hQRpwj5TcoPETepnoXHCUXzaCN/?watch=1603283195_1DruyFehQkemWTK5XKuFRpXb3tz89FFaVK. As far as I know, Cuba almost has zero access to the internet, and one who has it is always monitored. In the video, they have made a dedicated intranet called SNET (stands for Street Network), and many people gain access to it, mostly for games, and others for a dedicated web server for shopping.

But there's a problem, the network itself is quite unstable, likely if someone who is the main host or a bridge has died (disconnected), the network is partially "shut down". This can be annoying when you are on the internet and someone keeps dying on the line.

So, is ZeroNet really suitable for this type of network, I mean, we can create a never-die network for them. Can it be designed to work on this form of network? It would pretty much help the network stability. Plus number of people in this network are not that large already (around 20K)

1610267529_1BAG93hXwWmaDRyjYCGP8QLpwZ6YX.body:
I see you talk about password, I guess you may get it opposite. 

The whole idea of this network is about trust-based communication.

You don't need any sort of authentication (like password) at all, because you are, of course, the system owner, along with others which had their own system. All you do is sending and receiving contents from other users (peers). When you first join to the network, you just tell anyone that "hey, my name is ..., and here is my public key;:$@#%!" and publish it.

When you do something (in term of communication), you write data, and attach it with your public key and cryptographic signature, then publish them all over known users. They then will read the name & public key, if it is you (verified by your signature), they will likely keep it for others who do not have your data.

In term of signature, I mean the "digital signature", which is a pair of three things, private key, public key, and signature. They will be used by cryptographic mathematical calculation.

Private key is a key to keep secretly, and be used to encrypt or write a signature. That means you don't need a password, except in the case you want to lock (encrypt) the key inside your device.

Public key is, of course, a key to share with others. People will identify you with this thing, and also be used to verify a signature with a cryptographic methods.

Signature, is a cryptographic stream of bytes generated with a private key and stream of data as a template to ensure no one tamper your data and being sent safely.

No way it can be. It's just a favor of choice. As the best in can go, it'll never hit million concurrency.

The biggest roadblock of IPFS is stil a concept of 'identity', which there is no exact solution to be usable in the real world. As long as we still relies on trust-based mechanism, people still need to meet in-person to exchange security measurements to avoid using it. Another big roadblock is 'content distribution', that all of current centralized services also utilize the concept of 'decentralization' to provide as best of both worlds, but it'll less likely to happen on a 'true' distributed platform.
